title: Enable GitHub Advanced Security - Code Scanning for this repository
body:
# Rationale

Hello team,

First, a big thank you for this great work, you rock. I was wondering whether you'd like to appreciate [GitHub CodeQL code scanning](https://docs.github.com/en/code-security/code-scanning/automatically-scanning-your-code-for-vulnerabilities-and-errors/about-code-scanning) for this repository. This is free for public repository and can be useful to detect vulnerabilities in the code. 

As an example, I have forked the repo, enabled code scanning and found about 12 medium-to-high vulnerability in the whole C/Javascript/Go codebase. Of course, these vulnerabilities should be reviewed by security specialist to ensure they are not false-positive, but we never know!

I can share more details about these findings in private if needed.

I'm working at GitHub so I would be happy to help you if you're interested, it's pretty quick to setup and it would improve the overall security level of geth. 

# Implementation

Code scanning must be enabled by a repo admin in the repo settings.

Then, a GitHub Actions workflow file must be created for CodeQL, e.g. one like that:

```
name: "CodeQL"

on:
  push:
    branches: [ "master" ]
  pull_request:
    # The branches below must be a subset of the branches above
    branches: [ "master" ]
  schedule:
    - cron: '43 7 * * 5'
  workflow_dispatch:

jobs:
  analyze:
    name: Analyze
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    permissions:
      actions: read
      contents: read
      security-events: write

    strategy:
      fail-fast: false
      matrix:
        language: [ 'c', 'go', 'javascript' ]

    steps:
    - name: Checkout repository
      uses: actions/checkout@v3

    # Initializes the CodeQL tools for scanning.
    - name: Initialize CodeQL
      uses: github/codeql-action/init@v2
      with:
        languages: ${{ matrix.language }}
        # queries: security-extended,security-and-quality

    # Autobuild attempts to build any compiled languages  (C/C++, C#, Go, or Java).
    # If this step fails, then you should remove it and run the build manually (see below)
    - name: Autobuild
      uses: github/codeql-action/autobuild@v2

    - name: Perform CodeQL Analysis
      uses: github/codeql-action/analyze@v2
      with:
        category: "/language:${{matrix.language}}"
```

We could further secure the development lifecycle by setting this workflow as a required check in the branch protection rules of your main branch.

Hey there!

Why share the details in private if anyone can run the tool on their fork though? :)

I'd probably say that our interest would depend on the findings. We're probably very much open to tools that can find issues as long as it does not cause fatigue with the false positives.

> Why share the details in private if anyone can run the tool on their fork though? :)

You're very right :') I don't know, it's an old habit back in the days I was mostly focused on infosec.

To tell the truth, my knowledge in scanning tool and how they work is limited. I believe CodeQL is great and less prone to false-positives than some other industry-leading solutions, however it's impossible to guarantee it will never produce false-positives. 

I've just invited you to be a collaborator on my fork, where you'll be able to see the security alerts so you can have a better idea.
